Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Support for the Doctoral Colloquium at 2020 IEEE Visualization Conference (IEEE VIS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Visualization, the graphical representation of information and data, has become an integral part of data science with diverse and practical applications. This project is a travel grant that supports student attendees of the Doctoral Colloquium at the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Visualization Conference (IEEE VIS) 2020. The IEEE VIS conference is the premier forum for advances in visualization, which consists of IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology (VAST), IEEE Information Visualization (InfoVis), IEEE Scientific Visualization (SciVis), together with various workshops and associated events. The IEEE VIS 2020 conference will take place in Salt Lake City, Utah, between October 25 and October 30, 2020. The Doctoral Colloquium at IEEE VIS is a single-day event taking place the day before the IEEE VIS conference. It is a forum that fosters the growth of young researchers in the field of visualization. The colloquium began in 2006 and has been a highly successful event where Ph.D. students present their proposed dissertation work and receive mentorship from senior researchers. Many of its previous attendees have become leaders in visualization. The colloquium aims at diversity among the student participants. The diversity among students presenters and faculty panelists across multi-dimensions will help all participants to appreciate different perspectives and to think critically about diversity in education. The colloquium also helps to establish and strengthen professional networks and research collaborations among junior and senior researchers, which are beneficial for the junior researchers, and critical for the advancement of the field.

The award supports 18 Ph.D. students in visualization who are in the process of formulating or have just formulated a dissertation topic. During the colloquium, these students will discuss their research topics in a supportive environment with a panel of 6 to 8 distinguished researchers and faculties. They will also interact closely with their peers. They will receive feedback on their dissertation as well as advice on their career paths. The Doctoral Colloquium is a community-building experience that connects junior and senior researchers. It focuses on the participantsâ€™ doctoral dissertation research. The student participants are selected based on their research excellence and experiences. The colloquium also provides a forum for students to exchange research ideas, communicate their on-going works, and improve upon their research agendas. It encourages intellectual conversations and stimulating discussions. The works presented at the event also reflects the state-of-the-art in visualization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE Doctoral Colloquium (VIS DC) is an annual forum that fosters the growth of young researchers in the field of visualization. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent remote conferences, this project supported in part the VIS DC events that took place between the years 2020 and 2023. The VIS DC events (2020-2023) provided training, mentoring, and networking opportunities for the next generation of Ph.D. researchers in visualization. It included 18 participants in 2020, 13 in 2021, 16 in 2022, and 16 in 2023, respectively.  Each DC event contains four parts, including introduction, technical presentations by students and feedback via multiple concurrent panels with senior researchers, common lunch (virtual or in-person), and roundtable discussion. 


First, these VIS DC events provided feedback to student participants on their dissertation topics. These events allowed students to discuss their research in a supportive atmosphere. The participants received feedback from their peers as well as senior researchers in the field who were not their doctoral advisors. This feedback and guidance from senior researchers provided fresh perspectives for their dissertation topics and potentially helped them broaden their research agenda beyond their active dissertation topics to establish the next steps in their career.


Second, these VIS DC events provided mentoring opportunities. Roundtable discussions and interactions among participants (panelists and students) throughout the day of the event helped to broaden students’ perspectives beyond the completion of their Ph.D., including career paths, job search, grant writing, etc.


Third, these events allowed student participants to create a professional network both among themselves and with senior researchers, and to broaden their horizons at critical stages of their career. They served as a community-building opportunity that connects early career and senior researchers in visualization. They helped to establish a cohort of young researchers across the world. They provided ample opportunities for students to socialize with peers as well as senior researchers via a common lunch, panel, and round-table discussions. 


The DC events were committed to achieving diversity among the student participants and faculty panelists, including diversity across underrepresented groups and geographical areas. Such diversity helped all student and faculty participants to gain different perspectives across multiple dimensions. The events established and strengthened networks and collaborations among participants to advance the visualization field.
